key takeaways for quick navigation stress and burnout are prevalent issues with of people struggling with stress and experiencing burnout stress is higher than ever with of people having at least one feature of burnout and its affecting all age groups and industries an inability to disconnect from work including checking your phone excessively can be a sign of atypical burnout true resilience involves honoring boundaries selfcompassion and making space for rest and recovery not toxic resilience driven by productivity at all costs the rise in stress and burnout is not due to generational differences but is influenced by the hyperconnected world and collective trauma stress can have various physical manifestations like palpitations headaches neck pain and more these are unique to individuals and can be seen as their canary in the coal mine indicating stress the canary in the coal mine is a historical reference from coal mining where a canary was used to detect bad air quality similarly people have their own stress signals or canary songs that indicate stress its essential to see a doctor for a full workup to rule out any organic problems when experiencing stressrelated symptoms understanding your bodys physical manifestations of stress is crucial because these symptoms can serve as your personal canary song the main highway of stress in the brain and body is the hpa hypothalamicpituitaryadrenal axis which involves hormones like cortisol and adrenaline stress is not contagious like a virus but emotions and vibes can be contagious in social interactions the therapeutic presence in a doctorpatient relationship is essential for better health outcomes it involves qualities like authenticity empathy and making eye contact positive lifestyle changes even when beneficial can be stressful for the brain and may not last the rule of two suggests focusing on making two new changes at a time for better results the rule of two is based on a study by doctors holmes and rahi in the s which found that accumulating life events both positive and negative increased stress levels and the risk of developing illnesses later in life to make lasting changes its advised to implement two small changes at a time gradually building them into your routine whether its lifestyle changes or managing stress the first of the five resets to manage stress is to get clear on what matters most most to you this helps shift focus from selfpreservation to forward thinking and planning most stands for motivating objective small and timely its a framework to identify what goals matter most to you providing a roadmap to follow exercise even in small amounts can help manage stress it gets you out of your head increases selfefficacy and positively impacts mental health popcorn brain is a term describing the overstimulation and constant scrolling on our phones due to information overload its a common phenomenon in modern life the goal is not abstinence but creating digital boundaries with our phones to reduce reliance and decrease the number of times we check them thus improving mental health the speaker describes feeling in control most of the time but occasionally being in the back seat of life struggling to regain control emphasizing the importance of agency closing the gap between knowledge and action is essential and forming habits takes time emphasizing the importance of small consistent steps people should exercise for mental health benefits not just physical appearance and even a short walk can have a positive impact on stress and mental wellbeing taking short breaks during the day can help manage stress and boost productivity as demonstrated by a study from microsoft labs stress isnt necessarily bad its about maintaining a balance between healthy manageable stress and unhealthy stress the gutbrain connection is crucial for mental health and focusing on prebiotic and probiotic foods can help reset this connection watching the news late at night eating processed foods and having erratic meal times can contribute to stress and disrupt sleep multitasking is a myth true productivity comes from monotasking focusing on one task at a time as multitasking weakens the brains prefrontal cortex time blocking like the pomodoro technique involves setting a timer for focused work intervals eg minutes followed by short breaks which improves productivity and reduces stress multitasking can increase stress and reduce a sense of accomplishment so practicing monotasking through time blocking is more effective for productivity and mental wellbeing diaphragmatic breathing involves expanding the belly when inhaling and exhaling slowly which activates the parasympathetic nervous system reducing stress and increasing presence stop breathe and be for seconds to tap into the mindbody connection reduce stress and improve presence and focus expressive or therapeutic writing where you write about a traumatic event for minutes daily for four days can enhance mood sleep and overall wellbeing live a lifetime in a day involves incorporating elements of a meaningful life such as childhood work solitude vacation family and retirement even briefly each day to feel fulfilled and avoid the negative effects of hustle culture to counteract the negative impact of excessive phone use establish a media diet with time limits eg minutesday geographical limits keep the phone out of arms reach and logistical limits to maintain better mental health and reduce stress being informed and protecting mental health is essential seek help if facing mood disorders or anxiety hyperconnectivity and overconsumption of news can impact mental health negatively loneliness levels are rising globally and loneliness has significant health consequences comparable to smoking external appearances dont always reflect internal experiences be kinder and considerate to others chronic stress should not be glamorized aim for happiness fulfillment and connection in life made with harpa ai

clean_text: after a concentrated years of chronic stress graduating college moving out for the first time getting married starting a new career buying a house managing a touring band renovating our house marital issues etc i began have crippling pain in my sideabdomen it was so intense that i couldnt get dressed in the morning shower eat or sleep all the way through the night i lost of my body weight down to lbs over months and couldnt even work at my office job after another years of trying to live through daily crippling pain and seeing countless doctors around the pnw i finally landed on a gi specialist that happened to be studying the effects of stress and anxiety and its relation to gi pain he explained how certain antidepressants have been seen to help the miscommunication in the gutbrain connection although doctors dont know exactly why yet we tried different antidepressants at very low dosage levels and my pain is drastically lowersome days nonexistent and ive gained back half of the weight i lost in the last months we expect that it will be a while on this medication while my brain trains itself back to a healthy baseline rather than constantly being in fightorflight aside from or possibly a sideeffect of taking the medication i generally dont let little things bother me anymore and can let things go without stewing on them or catastrophizing when work is done for the day i genuinely let it be done and will sit and watch a show with my wife at the end of the day and actually let myself get engaged with the story ive become a better friend to people in general while not letting their problems become my own stress buildup legitimately ruined my life for years im so glad that its effects on our body are finally coming to light

world leading to an increase in mental health issues the canary in the coal mine concept is a metaphor for physical manifestations of stress with each individual having unique symptoms like hypothalamus pituitary gland adrenal glands releasing hormones like cortisol during the stress response stress is not directly contagious like a virus but emotional vibes and a persons presence can health outcomes authenticity vulnerability and the human voice play a vital role in creating connections making podcasting an intimate experience for listeners the resilience rule of two emphasizes how the brain embraces change suggesting that focusing on a couple of manageable changes can lead to longterm positive transformations positive life changes even if beneficial can be a stressor to the brain the rule of two suggests focusing on two changes at a time for lasting impact on managing stress making small incremental changes is more effective in managing stress than attempting large overhauls the five resets methodology emphasizes working with the biology of stress over time the first reset is to get clear on what matters most most using an acronym for motivating objective small and timely goals this helps shift focus from whats the matter with me to what matters most to me the importance of setting motivating objective small and timely goals to guide efforts in managing stress reallife examples demonstrate the impact of such goals on stress reduction incorporating small regular physical activities even just walking can significantly contribute to stress management its not about intense exercise but about consistent enjoyable movement popcorn brain refers to the overstimulation of the brain due to excessive time spent online particularly on social media creating digital boundaries rather than complete abstinence is key for mental wellbeing

Biological Gift Adapting Recovering and Growing in the Face of Challenges Toxic Resilience Promoting Mind Over Matter Is Detrimalal and Needs to Be Addressed Generational Comparisons on Resilience Are Invalid Younger Generations Face Different Challenges In a Hyperconnected World Issues the canary in the coal mine concept is a metaphor for physical manifestations of stress with each individual having unique symptoms like palpitations or gastrointestinal issues of the historical reference of the canary in the coal mine symbolizes a warnings a warning sign individuals have Their Own Stress Indicators and Recognizing Them is Crucial Highachievers May Deny Vulnerability to Stress Leading to Burnout Acknowledging Stress is a human experience not a sign of weakness the impact of stress on the brain involves the hp Hormones like cortisol during the stress response stress is not directly continuous like a virus but emotional vibes and a persons presence can influence others through hormones and a shared energetic field creating a therapeutic presence. Authenticity Impacting the Quality of Interaction and Health Outcomes Authenticity Vulnerability and the Human Voice Play a Vital Role in Creating Connection Making Podcasting an Intimate Experience for Listeners The Resilience Rule Of Two Emphasizes How The Brain Embraces Changesting That Focusing on a couple of manageable changes can lead to longterm positive transformations life changes even if benefits can be a stressor to the brain in managing stress than attempting large overhauls the five resets methodology emphasizes working with the biology of stress over time the first reset is to get clear on what matters most mostly use an acronym for motivating objectives and timely goals. with me to what matters most to me the importance of setting motivating objectives small and timely goals to guide efforts in managing stress reallife examples demonstrate the impact of such goals on stress reduction incorporating smalla stress management its not about intense exercise but about consistent enjoyable movement popcorn brain refers to the overstimulation of the brain due to excessive time spent online particularly on social media creating digital boundaries rather than complete abstinence is the key for mental wellbeing

clean_text: key takeaways for quick navigation stress and burnout are prevalent with of people struggling with stress and experiencing features of burnout stress levels have risen significantly affecting people across all ages and industries becoming a global concern burnout is no longer limited to traditional symptoms it can manifest as an inability to disconnect from work even if you enjoy it true resilience involves honoring boundaries selfcompassion and rest while toxic resilience focuses on productivity at all costs generations like gen z are not necessarily less resilient but face different challenges including collective trauma and hyperconnectivity the canary in the coal mine is a metaphor for physical manifestations of stress like palpitations headaches and more which act as signals of underlying stress in individuals admitting to stress is not a sign of weakness and even resilient individuals can experience burnout if they dont acknowledge their stress stress affects the brain and body through the hypothalamicpituitaryadrenal hpa axis leading to the release of hormones like cortisol resulting in the fight or flight response stress itself is not contagious like a virus but emotions and vibes can be contagious in social situations primarily through nonverbal cues and the voice creating a therapeutic presence involves factors like making eye contact being at the same or lower eye level mirroring and most importantly authenticity in human interactions our brains can struggle to sustain positive changes under stress as they perceive even positive changes as stressors the rule of two suggests focusing on making only two new changes at a time when dealing with stress or major life events when stressed its crucial to get clear on what matters most most setting motivating objective small and timely goals even a small amount of daily physical activity like a minute walk can significantly reduce stress and increase selfefficacy popcorn brain is a term for our brains overstimulation due to excessive smartphone use often driven by stress and constant information streams setting digital boundaries is key to managing it stress management requires recognizing when youre in control and when youre not allowing you to regain agency over time closing the gap between knowledge and action is crucial for effective stress management small consistent actions such as short walks are more effective than ambitious stressful goals in managing stress people often exercise for mental health benefits more than physical ones emphasizing the importance of stress management taking regular breaks even as short as seconds can help manage stress and boost productivity by aiding neural consolidation multitasking is a misnomer its actually task switching which weakens the prefrontal cortex affecting problemsolving concentration and mood in a complex world its essential to practice monotasking instead of multitasking for better brain health time blocking pomodoro technique helps protect and strengthen the prefrontal cortex by focusing on one task for a set time leading to reduced stress diaphragmatic breathing inhaling through the nose and exhaling through the mouth slowly can help reduce stress by activating the parasympathetic nervous system therapeutic writing expressing thoughts and emotions about a traumatic event for several days can improve mood sleep and reduce stress consuming excessive news stress and doom scrolling can lead to mental health issues including ptsd being an informed citizen is crucial but setting digital boundaries and limiting exposure to graphic content is essential to protect your mental health hyperconnectivity can lead to loneliness which is associated with various health risks such as heart disease and a shorter lifespan external appearances often dont reflect internal struggles so its important to be kind and empathetic towards others chronic stress should not be glamorized and finding a balanced approach to stress is essential for happiness fulfillment and connection made with harpa ai

i am a yearold senior citizenretired i take care of my yearold husband with increasing adhd cognitive decline and mobility decline as well my rescue dog that requires a lot of time and energy i make it my priority to go to my senior center two days a week in order to prevent depression stress and isolation i try to stay in touch with friends and family i do pretty well in the summer when the sun shines and i can get outside and enjoy exercise sunshine and fresh air however i live in michigan where we have months of cold high winds and snow which also combines to isolate us in our tiny condo i also prioritize a monthly massage as an additional stress reducing technique i diffuse lavender essential oil day and night as another way to relax my body i eat a nutrient rich diet aging health issues and financial issues are hard to manage but i do the best i can on a tight retirees budget

key takeaways for quick navigation of people are struggling with stress and have at least one feature of burnout indicating a significant rise in mental health problems increased rates of depression sleep disorders fatigue and burnout are observed due to higher stress levels with of patient visits having a stressrelated component people experience an inability to disconnect from work with statistics showing individuals checking their phones up to times a day contributing to a sense of burnout dr aditi narukas journey as a stress expert began when she as a stressed medical student couldnt find help she became the doctor she needed uncovering solutions beyond mere relaxation unprecedented levels of stress are observed globally affecting all industries and demographics mental health stress and burnout are gaining recognition breaking taboos in various sectors stress rates are at an alltime high with of people experiencing burnout and struggling with stress the recent years have been noted as the most stressful in many professionals careers the difference between acute and chronic stress is explained emphasizing that chronic stress leading to burnout doesnt allow the brain time to rest or recharge impacting overall wellbeing burnout symptoms are evolving with of cases showing an inability to disconnect from work atypical burnout can manifest in seemingly engaged individuals who struggle to unplug addiction to work can be a sign of burnout when it interferes with sleep relationships and daily life highlighting the changing face and definition of burnout toxic resilience characterized by productivity at all costs and a mindovermatter mindset is contrasted with true resilience emphasizing the need for rest recovery and selfcompassion the societal glorification of toxic resilience reflected in messages like keep calm and carry on contributes to the misconception that dealing with discomfort is the essence of resilience which needs to be debunked resilience is discussed in the context of different generations challenging the stereotype that older generations were more resilient due to harder labor with the acknowledgment that each generation faces unique challenges the canary in the coal mine analogy explains the physical manifestations of stress it refers to our bodys unique signals indicating stress like palpitations headaches or gastrointestinal issues the hpa axis hypothalamus pituitary adrenal is the brains stress information highway chronic stress keeps this axis active leading to persistent hormone surges especially cortisol causing various health issues stress is not contagious like a virus but emotions and vibes can be the hearts electromagnetic field may influence how people perceive each others vibes or emotional states the therapeutic encounter in healthcare involves creating a sense of equality compassion and empathy simple actions like sitting at eye level can enhance the perceived care and engagement in medical interactions authenticity in the human voice plays a crucial role in building connections the voice triggers deepseated instincts from infancy fostering a sense of authenticity vulnerability and likability in human interactions the resilience rule of two explains how our brains adapt to change positive changes require embracing discomfort twice first accepting the change and second adapting to the new situation fostering brain plasticity positive lifestyle changes such as reducing stress can be challenging to sustain due to the brains limited capacity for simultaneous changes the rule of two is based on a study by holmes and rahi suggesting that positive life changes also stress the brain advising to focus on two changes at a time for effective adaptation in clinical practice incremental changes by focusing on two aspects at a time are emphasized for managing stress and achieving longterm goals the first reset involves getting clear on what matters most most motivating objective small timely to combat stress and engage the prefrontal cortex for better decisionmaking the stress score helps in the first reset understanding the patients stress level while setting most goals motivating objective small timely creates a roadmap for stress management exercise even in small amounts like a minute walk has significant benefits for stress management and mental health improving selfefficacy and reducing anxiety popcorn brain is a term for the brains overstimulation due to excessive online activity driven by a primal urge to constantly scan for danger especially during stressful times to combat popcorn brain its essential to establish digital boundaries and reconsider the relationship with the phone rather than seeking complete abstinence aiming for a healthier use stressinduced emotional eating is a biological response the amygdala focused on survival craves highfat highsugar foods during stressful periods understanding and managing these cravings is crucial acknowledge the struggle with stress but focus on regaining control practice and knowledge help closing the gap between knowledge and action is crucial for habitbuilding and stress reduction start with small achievable actions for stress relief such as a minute walk to build momentum exercise for mental health rather than cosmetic reasons even a minute walk positively impacts stress biology honor breaks in the workday microsoft study shows that minute breaks reduce stress and boost mood not all stress is bad differentiate between adaptive good and maladaptive bad stress for a healthier life foster a healthy gutbrain connection through sleep diet exercise and stress reduction focus on prebiotic and probiotic foods humorous but poignant the day plan to maximize anxiety and stress involves habits like latenight screen exposure and irregular eating multitasking weakens the prefrontal cortex impacting problemsolving concentration mood and engagement monotasking through time blocking is a more effective approach diaphragmatic breathing also known as belly breathing is an effective stress reduction technique inhale through the nose expand the belly and exhale slowly through the mouth stop breathe be a quick mindfulness technique to switch from the sympathetic to the parasympathetic nervous system reducing stress and promoting presence therapeutic writing expressive writing for minutes daily about a traumatic event has been proven to improve mood sleep anxiety and even increase gpa live a lifetime in a day incorporate elements of childhood work solitude vacation family and retirement daily to bring fulfillment and meaning into life countering the hustle culture implement a media diet by setting time limits keeping the phone away during work and creating logistical boundaries reducing stress and enhancing mental health consuming graphic content such as videos and images increases the risk of ptsd and mental health conditions emphasizing the need for moderation and awareness in media consumption being an informed citizen is crucial but establishing digital boundaries is equally important for mental health overconsumption of news especially graphic content can lead to mental health issues seek counseling if experiencing distress excessive phone use contributes to a sense of hyperconnectivity but actual disconnection fueling a global loneliness epidemic loneliness is a health concern equated to smoking cigarettes a day increasing heart disease and stroke risks internal experiences may not align with external appearances kindness is vital as everyone is facing unseen struggles stress and resilience terminologies need reframing chronic stress should not be glamorized and a nuanced middle ground is crucial empathetic communication is key understanding the humanity in individuals work fosters connection and success feedback is valuable continuous learning and reinforcing beliefs through feedback contribute to personal and professional growth

clean_text: worklife balance is about finding a healthy and sustainable way to manage both your professional and personal responsibilities its important to set clear boundaries and prioritize your time according to your values and goals take time to recharge and invest in your wellbeing through activities like exercise hobbies and spending time with loved ones additionally communicate your needs and limitations with your employer and colleagues remember worklife balance is a continuous process that requires ongoing evaluation and adjustment by finding a balance that works for you you can enhance your productivity creativity and overall happiness
translated: Worklife Balance is about Finding a Healthy and Sustainable Way to Manage Both Your Professional and Personal Responsibility Its Important to Set Clear Boundaries and Prioritize Your Time According to your values ​​and goals take time to recharge and invest in your wellbeing Exercise Hobbies and Spending Time with Loved Ones Additionally Communicate Your Needs and Limitations with your Employer and Colleague Remember Worklife Balance is a Continuous Process that Requires Ongoing Evaluation and adjust Productivity Creativity and Overall Happiness

clean_text: my notes if memory and focus arent working how you want them to it can be stress related stress affects two areas of the brain the frontal lobe the area for working memory keeping emotions under control goal setting making plans prioritizing what to do first next etc and the hippocampus which is the core of our memory highstress hormones shrink the cells in the frontal lobe and hippocampus the best thing you do for your brain is to be physically active when were working out its not just good because our heart starts pumping and we get oxygen to our brain but while we are physically active our brain makes growth factor that stimulates the outgrowth of the branches in brain cells they reestablish contact with each other maybe even new cells are formed it doesnt have to be a marathon research shows that people who do a brisk minute walk times per week gave a bigger hippocampus than people who only do stretching exercises sleeping well is the second very important thing you can do sleep loss is a chronic stressor even after one night of poor sleep results in poorer concentration memory and irritability during sleep our brain reorganizes itself good connections are strengthened and bad connections are removed sleep washes the brain clean of waste products we need that for a good working brain your brain needs good building blocks ie food its hard to pinpoint which vitamins or minerals are good for your brain but for a whole eating pattern its clear that people who eat a mediterranean diet have a brain for a longer time with better memory and concentration a mediterranean diet is large amounts of fruits vegetables fish which provide omega fatty acids we cannot make them ourselves other proteins and grains and healthy fats olive and nutsin some studies these seem to be the two secret ingredients that keep your brain healthy for a long time red wine is not good for your brain meditating is the fourth thing you can do for your brain increased scientific research shows that daily meditation can benefit your focus and attention in a basic way meditation trains your attention and emotional control you can start with five minutes a day and see how it goes you can try it for example five minutes daily when you wake up or before bed these four adjustments can counteract the devastating effects of chronic stress and make your brain resilient to it nilki built these areas into her routine after getting burned out through work she feels her brain works well again maybe even better than ever and she now knows its perfectly fine to work hard and long hours as long as she takes good care of her brain be good to your brain its the crown of who you are treat her like a queen

hey dr k ive learned a lot from you so far and im really grateful for that now that were getting into economics and the reasons why its becoming harder for people to make a living i hope i can show you something in return the reason why were being paid less and less over time isnt because of efficiency or because weve figured things out its due to the inflationary monetary system technological progress and increased efficiency should actually mean that everything becomes cheaper over time because we can produce things more effectively but heres the problem lets say people have become on average more efficient at producing goods that would typically lead to deflation a decrease in prices however since central banks have a mandate to aim for inflation ie price increases they will actively work against that deflation this means any natural deflation is systematically eliminated and on top of that an additional inflation is deliberately targeted unfortunately the incentives are also set up so that central banks always manage to achieve those inflation figures and since they calculate inflation themselves they also have an incentive to make the numbers look better than they are for example by adjusting the basket of goods used to measure inflation to include cheaper or lowerquality items that have lower price increases while removing higherquality goods that have risen more in price on top of that the cpi consumer price index only includes consumer goods it excludes assets like real estate since rising credit levels dont necessarily lead to a proportional increase in demand for consumer goods but rather for assets like real estate asset prices tend to rise far more than the cpi does because wages are usually only adjusted according to the cpi which as mentioned is both manipulated and incomplete real wages fall over time in terms of what people can actually afford thats why it keeps getting harder to make ends meet even though on paper it looks like wages millennial here something ive noticed over the years with enjoyment of work and maybe it could be expanded on a bit the term enjoy doesnt mean im having fun and everything is smiles and happiness unless you are in a rare super lucky situation try to frame it as i feel my work is important i know what i need to be competent and accomplish the work and i have the autonomy to complete it if you are passionate about something and are rewarded in the ways that matter to you the time you spend working on it becomes insignificant and the tiredness you feel each day week is more like a levellingup experience that can fluctuate depending on the context and role you are in but when it starts to trend toward not important not clear and or not autonomous then you are probably not enjoying the work dr k has great videos on burnout relating to this then there is the tiredness factor of this video older generations benefitted from the relative calm of life without the internet and everything was accessed through physical participation which set up resilient habits to live well on in general this is what dr k is referring to about exercise and tiredness an athletes tiredness is no different to an amateurs tiredness except for the amount of practice theyve had at getting tired and noticing improvements over time the problem we face now is that we are oversaturated with digital access to infinite information so the older generations have the advantage of those established habits but the younger gens are less likely to have those natural skills and some dont know how to step away from it something that used to be normal and was easy to access before the internet became ubiquitous in the late s early s we might have a few select advantages but there are so many external debuffs stacked on us that simply pushing a high amount of effort is quickly negated by the elite endgame players so society now has no choice but to apply substantial effort to avoid the saturated noise so that we can fit enjoyment of things back in to our preinternet biology we actually have to perform work on enjoyment of work so that the work we perform is actually enjoyable p

as a yearold gen z professional with two years of work experience ive developed a clear what i can do about it philosophy for navigating my career and personal growth embrace calculated risks playing it safe wont get me where i want to be im choosing to embrace more risk particularly in my investments and career path for instance im shifting away from overpriced bluechip stocks and opting for more dynamic investments while most of my current portfolio is in gold a hedge against potential global instability im also willing to jobhop more frequently this includes taking on roles with the inherent risk of not passing probation or being among the first for layoffs master the ai revolution i believe were at a pivotal point similar to how ancient rome transitioned to a slavebased economy ultimately leading to chaos due to unemployment our world faces a similar threat with the rise of ai to thrive we must learn to leverage ai to automate work through products and services my focus is on deeply understanding how to build design market and utilize ai cultivate hope and connection as highlighted in various discussions maintaining a sense of future prospect is crucial for sustained energy and motivation my personal goal is to gain experience in a developed country for years before returning to southeast asia this offers significant leverage due to currency differences its about finding your own version of hope that fuels your drive prioritize fast recharge hobbies and meaningful friendships i used to maintain an intense hour workday including weekends balancing a startup job and college while i gradually built up to this workload i found myself completely exhausted and lost after about years now that ive graduated i prioritize fast recharge hobbies instead of mindlessly scrolling social media im selective about consuming highly recommended anime or manga ive also gravitated towards upbeat music and most importantly i dedicate time to friends with whom i have genuine connections im not afraid to cut off relationships that dont serve me or limit interactions to once a quarter if thats whats best for my wellbeing

i like how you talk about it being expectations based an anecdote from my own life i went though all of elementary middle and high school never procrastinating and studying a lot and making sure i got all straight as cuz i was told by the shcools that i needed to do that to get into a good college so i could get a good job and live a good life my parents never really hounded on me cuz i did get straight as all the time so then i get into the good college and again i never procrastinating and studied a lot and made sure i got straight as most of the time so i could then get a good job i also played a sport in college like i did in school growing up and i wanted to play more so i took a masters program at the same college same thing again dont procrastinate use all the campus resources study hard i graduated at the top of the class for my cohort so then im like okay sick now i get to get a job and be set the rest of my life a couple months go by no real progress with interviews thats okay its the summer and im enjoying having finished all my schooling thats fine i move back in with my parents more months go by no job theyre like hey man you need to have a job and im like i thought i was supposed to have one by now i did all the steps i sacrificed having a ton of fun because i was forwarding thinking trying to better my future self a couple more months go by and i find some part time work to appease my parents i still havent found a job related to my masters degree after over a year finally after a couple more months i get an offer to work full time its not very much pay but at least its something and i end up having to move across the entire country to do it i think for a lot of people who are around my age im rn its just sucks to feel like you followed the path you were told to follow and check all the boxes but life just doesnt actually work that way it kinda feels like we got lied to and then were expected to just hate ourselves and suffer so people who are super rich can get even richer a second anecdote related tertiary to what the girl int eh video was saying i truly and honestly have no clue how people in the generations before us had jobs and were able to live healthy lives i guess maybe they didntdont if you look at the illnesses so many people have but like i mentioned i played a sport in college and i still play it now and look i wasnt good enough to go pro but i was around people who did and we were all on the same team and so wed do the same habits tracking all your calories making sure youre eating the right macros optimizing your sleep working out at the gym training sessions mental performance work just general therapy and relaxation time to make sure you perform at your best working hours a day makes it extremely difficult to take care of your health youre stuck at work for those hours unable to leave so you need to do your gym time before or after but you also need to make sure to meal prep your lunch so you can eat something nutritious at work lunch so you need to sort out when you can go to the gym and when you can prep your meals that already cuts some hours out of your day then you have to commute to and from work and to and from the gym you can choose to do that before work or after work either of those choices will impact when you go to sleep but you need to make sure you can get at least hours of sleep to perform well when its all said in done you basically have hours left in each workday to use on leisure activities at least in my experience and maybe this is the privilege talking but how is that enough time and this is if you have the drive to actually be able to do the relaxing stuff like the girl said its exhausting working id never experienced stress in school because i would work ahead to finish all my assignments and prepare for my tests you have a rewarding period at the end that you work towards thats what we were taught in school but thats not what a is like it never ends there is no test theres nothing to study for theres no end why the heck are we taught this workflow pattern for our entire lives if thats not what the real world is like no wonder people dont eat healthy no wonder they dont work out no wonder they get poor sleep doing all those things to stay healthy takes some work and discipline but now youre getting yelled at by your boss at work in a constant state of stress with no end in sight people dont have the bandwidth for all of that the other generations having the audacity to call us lazy is myopic to me at least we had the drive to create some positive change for people to live healthier lives just because things have been done a certain way for a long time doesnt make them right and at least to me in the present day those methods dont work anymore idk would love to here any other gen z people my age give their thoughts on this is this how youre feeling too i know im currently trying to leave my current job and find something where you can actually live a healthy life maybe thats why so many people just become influencers its a way to have a balanced day even if its mostly pedaling scam products to impressionable people or rage baiting at least you have the opportunity to have some work life balance maybe im just salty that i wasnt good enough to go pro or i wasnt networked enough to get a really good job with my masters but it does kinda feel like i worked really hard for no reason well anyhoo these videos always help me out a lot when im struggling with stuff so keep up with the good content and i hope some other people get something from my text walls up there haha glhf

clean_text: ive been feeling burnt out for the past months from work the stress keeps piling on until one day i went into a mental breakdown my body triggered some safety mechanism and all my stress melted away however at the same time i found it super hard to think straight thats when i realized if i didnt stop its going to lead to a long time to recover if youre in that state or nearing the state because of constant stress i recommend taking proper breaks or rest period no job or school is worth destroying your mental or physical well being everything seems so large at that time but later on you realized its not so big at all im quitting my job and going backpacking for awhile i have enough funds to last me well over a couple months so ill be taking some time to recuperate if you dont have that opportunity i recommend following the video yet if its a job try finding another one its not worth destroying your health and wellbeing over a job theres plenty out there if youre in school follow what the video talks about also maybe think about doing a backpacking trip you can go on a low budget trip and still experience the world dont shirk your responsibility yet make sure its not the pressure from society friends parents or family forcing you into staying at a position you dont want to be burnout is a sign that our body tells us theres something wrong somethings not right its good because then we notice it to start changing our circumstances routines and lifestyle you are important and are full of dignity and selfworth jesus loves you you are so important to him you are worth dying for so that you can know god and be forgiven do not give up on yourself god did not give up on you you are of great value and worth to him dont give up if you cant do it trust in him he will give you the strength to keep going each and every day you are never alone he is faithful always jesus loves you

clean_text: posted this right when i needed it i hope you take a small moment out of your day to read this who ever is reading this cause i promise you it wont be a waste of your time since its a helpful piece of adviceinformation anxiety is like a fitful child think of a parent at the store and there child is taking a fit over not being able to get candy in the store they want if the parent gives into the child yelling and screaming and gets the candy to make them stop throwing a fit sure itll make the child be quiet faster but then the child will learn that taking a fit gets them what they want and will continue to do so and will even get more persistent with it but if the parent doesnt get the candy then the child will learn that screaming and taking a fit will not get them what they want if you think of it this way anxiety is a lot like a fitful child we tend to give into anxiety witch just teaches it that it can get what it wants by throwing a fit your anxiety usually wants something from you weather thats not hanging out with a friend cause of social anxiety or not decluttering cause you dont wanna deal with old things escaping with playing video games staying on your phone or looking up your symptoms on google for a little bit of reassurance cause your anxiety is yelling at you to do so but if you do it anyways and hang out with your friend or choose not to look up your symptoms your teaching your brain that taking a fit wont solve anything of course at first this may be annoying to hear this child screaming and yelling at you but if you dont give in and keep persistence eventually you will be dealing with little to no anxiety and your fitful child will understand that taking a fit doesnt get them what they want hope this helps tried making it as gender neutral as possible

clean_text: during my college enrollment i initially chose history geography and political science as my subjects however i soon became uncertain and was influenced by a friend who had opted for english literature instead of geography i decided to follow suit and switched to english literature abandoning geography interestingly prior to college i had chosen mathematics in my th and th grades but later regretted not pursuing it further instead i reapplied to reinstate geography as one of my subjects after two to three months i redeveloped an interest in english literature and decided to pursue it alongside geography and economics in addition to history throughout this process i experienced persistent confusion indecisiveness and an inability to maintain focus on a single subject these symptoms have led me to wonder if i might be experiencing adult attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd additional points to consider do you experience difficulties with organization time management and meeting deadlines have you noticed challenges with selfregulation of emotions leading to mood swings or irritability are you prone to impulsive decisions or actions which might be detrimental to your personal or professional life do you find it hard to maintain focus during conversations reading or other activities if you identify with several of these points it may be helpful to consult a mental health professional for a comprehensive evaluation and guidance

clean_text: i had these signs a couple years ago so i went to see a therapist i had been with therapists before but they all said i just need to push through and i kept thinking but it keeps getting worse and worse finally i start ending up in the nurse a lot finding myself out of class or skipping classes or something to avoid school and people kept telling me to push through and my anxiety will relieve with time and i find a therapist at one point and she understands me and she helpes me and she diagnoses me with add and when i was with the school therapist she never helped me she always said your have responsibilities and you need to fulfill them school is a priority and i swear i have always thought society thinks school and education and work is more important than your health and when i told the school therapist at this point my mind felt overwhelmed with emotion and i just wanted to end my life but the school therapist said this over my health add isnt real and that doesnt mean you can keep avoiding classes i have a condition thats an excuse and that was my burnout point now im doing better ive been on medication to help with my add stoped skipping classes and protested against that school therapist for running my life but now that i think about it my burnout point was the moment i started to get anxiety and skipping classes and such because people werent listening to me

clean_text: key insights on managing stress anxiety a neuroscientific perspective based on the huberman lab essentials episode stress as a brainbody phenomenon stress defined stress is a generalized system mobilizing brain and body resources when internal experiences clash with external demands it involves the sympathetic nervous system activation and parasympathetic nervous system calming neurological basis the sympathetic chain ganglia neurons along the spine release epinephrine adrenaline priming the body for action eg increased heart rate blood flow to muscles conversely the parasympathetic system slows bodily functions eg digestion during stress tools for immediate stress relief the physiological sigh mechanism a rapid breathing technique to counteract acute stress double inhale through the nose long exhale through the mouth why it works reinflates collapsed lung alveoli expels excess co and triggers the parasympathetic nervous system to lower heart rate effectiveness reduces stress within seconds repeat times as needed shortterm stress benefits immune activation positive role acute stress enhances immune function by releasing adrenaline which mobilizes infectionfighting cells eg from the spleen tool cyclic hyperventilation wim hof method protocol rapid inhalesexhales hold breath for seconds postexhale repeat cycles outcome boosts adrenaline combats infections and reduces inflammatory responses supported by studies on endotoxin tolerance caution avoid breathholding near water consult a doctor for preexisting conditions mediumterm stress raising stress threshold stress inoculation deliberately exposing oneself to stressors eg cold showers intense exercise to build tolerance tool cognitive calming under activation panoramic vision widen gaze avoid tunnel vision during high stress to activate brainstem circuits that reduce mental agitation practice during physical exertion eg sprinting consciously relax the mind while the body remains activated longterm stress mitigating chronic damage key risks chronic stress erodes brain structures eg hippocampus weakens immunity and increases cardiovascular risks critical tools social connection activates serotonin linked to wellbeing and neural repair prioritize trusted relationships pets or activities that spark delight supplements use judiciously ashwagandha lowers cortisol and anxiety shortterm use recommended ltheanine mg enhances relaxation and sleep quality via gaba modulation avoid highdose melatonin disrupts hormonal balance prioritize natural lightdark cycles for sleep organizational framework for emotional health three stress timescales acute secondsminutes use physiological sigh or cyclic breathing medium daysweeks build resilience via stress inoculation chronic monthsyears invest in social bonds sleep and antiinflammatory habits core principle stress is neither inherently good nor badits impact depends on context duration and controllability conclusion stress management requires a tailored sciencebacked approach leverage physiology use breathwork physiological sigh cyclic breathing to modulate acute stress build resilience train the mind to stay calm during physical activation eg panoramic vision prioritize connection social bonds and serotonin are foundational for longterm emotional health supplement strategically ashwagandha and ltheanine can aid stress modulation but are not substitutes for lifestyle fundamentals by understanding stress as a dynamic brainbody interplay we can harness its adaptive power while mitigating harm the key lies in realtime tools for acute relief deliberate practice for resilience and sustained investment in relationships and restorative habits stress is not your enemyits a signal your task is to decode it and respond with intention adapted from dr andrew huberman
translated: Key Insights on Managing Stress Anxiety a Neuroscientific Perspective Based on the Huberman Lab Essentials Episode Stress as a brainbody phenomenon stress Defined Stress is a Generalized Mobilizing System Brain and Body Resources When Internal Internal Experiences Clash With External Demands It InvoT Sympathetic Nervous System Activation and Parasympathetic Nervous System Calming Neurological Basis The Sympathetic Chain Ganglia Neurons Along The Spine Release Epinephrine Adrenaline Priming The Body For Action Eg Increased Heart Rate Rate Rate BLOOD TO Muscles Conversely Parasympathetic System Slows Bodily Bodily Functions Eg Digestion During Stress Tools for immediate stress reliefs the physical sigh mechanism a rapid breathing technique to counteract acute stress double inhale through Reinflates Collapsed Lung Alveoli Expels Excess Co. And Triggers The Parasympathetic Nervous System to Lower Heart Rate Effectiveness Reduces Stress Within Seconds Repeat Times As Needed Shortterm Stress Stress Benefits IMMUNE ACTIVATION POSITIVATION Releasing Adrenaline Which Mobilizes InfectionFighting Cells Eg From the Spleen Tool Cyclic Hyperventilation Wim Hof ​​Method Protocol Rapid Inhalesexhales Hold Breath for Seconds Postxhale Repeat Cycles Outcomes Outcome Responses Supported by Studies on Endotoxin Tolerance Caution Avoid Breatholding Near Water Consult a Doctor for Preexisting Conditions Medium Stress Raising Stress Threshold Stress Inoculation Deliberately Exposing Exposing onesel to Stressors Tool Cognitive Calming Under Activation Panoramic Vision Widen Gaze Avoid Tunnel Vision During High Stress to Activate Braintem Circuits that Reduce Mental Agitation Practice During Physical Exercise Eg Sprinting Consciously Mitigating Chronic Damage Key Risks Chronic Stress Erodes Brain Structures Eg Hippocampus Weakens Immunity and Increases Cardiovascular Risks Critical Tools Social Connection Activates Serotonin Linked to Wellbeing and Neural Replay Prioritize Prioritize Trusted Relationships that spark delight supplements use judiciously ashwagandha lowers cortisol and anxiety shortterm use recommended ltheanine mg enhances relaxation and sleep quality via gaba modulation avoid highdose melatonin disruption disrupts hormonal balance prioritize natural lights. Cycles for Sleep Organizational Framework for Emotional Health Three Stress Timescales Acute Secondsminutes Use Physiological Sigh or Cyclic Breathing Medium Daysweeks Build Resilience via Stress Inoculation Chronic MonthSyears Habits Core Principle Stress is Neither inherently Good Nor Badits Impacts Depends on Context Duration and Controllation Conclusion Stress Management Requires a Tailored ScienceBacked Approach Leverage Physiology Use Breathwork Physiological Physiological Build Resilience Train The Mind to Stay Calm During Physical Activation Eg Panoramic Vision Prioritize Connection Social Bonds and Serotonin Are Foundational For Longterm Emotional Health Health Supplement Strategic Ashwagandha and Ltheanine Can Aid Stress Stress Stress Moduction But Are Not Substitutes For Longterm Fundamentals by Understanding Stress as a dynamic brainbody interplay we can harness its adaptive power while mitigating harm the key lies in realtime tools for acute relief deliberate practice for resilience and sustained investment in relationships signal your task is to decode it and respond with intention adapted from Dr. Andrew Huberman

this is about the third video that is explaining a topic in a really poor manner i have no idea what the hell shes talking about seems very superficial to what ive experienced ive went through burnout myself and im still recovering with me it was a high level of physical emotional and mental exhaustion i was completely drained i reached a point where i completely dissassociated from my body i was with my partner and he was talking to me calling me even held me and i completely was unable to move or react or reply i would often feel extremely anxious on not knowing where id be able to find any kind of energy or strength to face the next day i was working about to hours per day i very often worked during weekends and on holidays this went on for basically five years i eventually starting having panic attacks and suicidal thoughts this all culminated on a stroke i suffered this march and ive been recovering ever since ive been seen by a psychiatrist a psychologist a neurologist a general practice doctordid countless exams and been on different medication since i took a medical leave of months after my stroke and went back to the same job afterwards needless to say it very quickly started all getting the same again yes the feeling of unffairness was there but that exists in every aspect of your life what is really fair anyways extrinsic rewards or whatever she was talking about seeking some kind of appreciation for what were bringing on to the table i think thats pretty normal so again dont understand how thats a symptom on my end if i would offer any kind of advice is if you ever feel and heres the important part not a bit or not just occasionally but often terribly overwhelmed do something about it right away communicate it to your line manager try to do your job during your working hours and if it proves to be impossible communicate that to your manager if even after you established boundries and provided regular and formal feedback on whats happening and nothing changes leave leave before it gets worse before your body and your health forces you to no job is worth your life i was an overachiever constantly trying to do everything and as much as possible constantly wanting to be the best possible employee i could be constantly trying to help everyone around me constantly trying to push myself and telling myself that i was strong enough to endure anything look where that got meand yes i did leave my job three weeks ago im now taking some time off and recovering at home with my partner and im still struggling on a day to day basis but i can see some small improvements already and i believe in a few months ill hopefully start feeling better and more like myself

so i was diagnosed with depersonalizationderealization disorder over a decade ago fortunately most of the symptoms are gone thankfully because its disconcerting to experience those dissociative symptoms randomly how my therapist described it to me and my own lived experience was that depersonalization is like living in a waking dream where youre there but not really there reality doesnt feel real and neither do you like when i looked down at my hand i wouldnt recognize it as my hand during an episode it was like i was disconnected from my body and sometimes felt as if i were floating outside of myself completely disengaged from my own sensesexperiences i didnt experience that sense of cynicism like she talked about though i guess the closest to that i experienced was just feeling emotionally numb but that was a feeling of nothingness like my emotions were under a frozen lake theyre there but i just cant access them to feel them feeling a sense of cynicism would be actually feeling that emotion though i have no doubts that my chronic stress intensified the symptoms of depersonalization not feeling like a person and derealization not feeling that reality is real though i just didnt have the phrase burnout in my vocabulary years ago i wonder if she just misspoke when she said depersonalization

clean_text: the conceptualization and recognition of burnout vary significantly between countries notably between sweden and the usa these differences reflect broader attitudes towards work mental health and wellbeing as well as the influence of healthcare systems and cultural norms on the understanding of psychological syndromes sweden in sweden burnout is recognized with a particular emphasis on its severe physiological and psychological impacts the swedish approach to understanding and treating burnout includes medical recognition burnout is recognized as a serious medical condition that can lead to profound physical and mental exhaustion significant memory loss inability to concentrate and even physical incapacity to perform daily tasks symptomatology the symptoms associated with burnout in sweden encompass more than just emotional exhaustion or cynicism related to work it includes severe symptoms such as changes in brain function memory loss and an overall inability to function in daily life treatment approach sweden has specialized clinics for the treatment of burnout indicating a structured healthcare approach to address the syndrome the treatment is comprehensive potentially involving medical psychological and occupational interventions cultural context the swedish approach reflects a broader societal recognition of the importance of worklife balance mental health and the physiological impacts of chronic stress united states in the united states the understanding of burnout particularly in the medical and occupational context has traditionally been more focused on the psychological aspects though this is expanding definition burnout in the us is often defined by the world health organizations description focusing on three main dimensions emotional exhaustion depersonalization and reduced personal accomplishment primarily in the context of the workplace recognition and treatment while awareness of burnout is increasing in the us it has not traditionally been recognized as a medical diagnosis by itself in the general healthcare system treatment and recognition might vary greatly depending on the healthcare provider with a focus often placed on stress management mental health counseling and lifestyle adjustments research and discussion the discussion around burnout in the us has been growing especially in the context of workplace wellness programs and within specific professions with high levels of occupational stress such as healthcare and technology cultural context the us work culture which often values long hours and high productivity may contribute to the prevalence of burnout however there is an increasing push towards recognizing the importance of mental health and worklife balance comparison the key differences between sweden and the usa in defining and treating burnout lie in the recognition of the conditions severity and the scope of symptoms considered swedens approach is more medicalized recognizing severe physiological symptoms and changes in brain function as part of the syndrome this leads to a comprehensive treatment approach that includes specialized clinics in contrast the us has traditionally focused on the psychological aspects of burnout with a growing but still evolving recognition of its seriousness and implications for health care and workplace policies both countries are moving towards a better understanding and management of burnout reflecting a global shift in recognizing mental health as a critical component of overall wellbeing however swedens approach by including more severe symptoms and a structured healthcare response indicates a more advanced recognition of burnout as a significant health issue that requires specialized treatment

clean_text: burnout can happen from work life in general as well as medical care i am retired and the first two do not apply but after serious illness i became overwhelmed by continuous medical intervention month after month it started with being misdiagnosed twice over a two year period cancer surgery radiation therapy radiation disease and treatment for incontinence issues made worse by having my bladder toasted after tweaking my diet from being vegetarian to eating plantbased whole foods organic where possible high fiber low fat low protein no sugar processed foods or alcohol along with taking a few supplements and losing lbs my oncologist was so impressed she told me that my risk of recurrence is now only something she repeated during my last three or four surveillance appointments i consulted her about bulkamid but have so far taken prescription med declined pt had a metronic interstim device implanted bladder botox a pessary and bulkamid symptoms have improved a little certainly not enough to significantly improve my quality of life in fact i have another appointment with the gynurologist next month she will likely suggest more bulkamid injections andor a urethral sling i also see my pcp for a couple of chronic conditions after reaching the two year cancer survival mark i decided stop surveillance appointments my oncologist is highly respected so i feel able to trust her when she says my cancer is very unlikely to return of course she expressed looking forward to seeing me dealing wth other medical issues is more than enough to cope with especially when i am keen to live life free of medical intervention i have had enough of frequent and serious medical mistakes enough is enough and as soon as i can stop seeing the gynurologist who custom programmed my interstim which was not working i intend to do so instead ill continue to spend my time persuing a healthy lifestyle i have no interest in cancer support groups and see no reason to look back i am the captain of my ship that said i am grateful for a few counseling sessions which helped me reinvent my life to be in alignment with my values and get the most bang for my buck from whatever time remains no doubt my choices would not be everyones but in my case thats what works for me and brings peace

clean_text: i experienced burn out a couple years ago i was working for a company that i didnt align with morally in a role where i was asking to do questionable things and too much work to complete in a work day after years i finally just broke i took a week off and spent most of those days just crying without really knowing why i had never felt something like that before at the end of the week i told my supervisor what was going on and decided to take a leave of absence to get things figured out i went back to therapy and also paired with a career coach that month changed my life i felt like i had to rebuild myself entirely and my therapist and coach helped me realize i needed to be doing something different my company couldnt support my new career goal so i ended up taking a huge leap and leaving the company to pursue my new career hoping a new company would take a chance on me with little to no experience im so much happier and at peace with my new career and company im so blessed that i had a supervisor who supported what i needed and gave me the space to do it i was also very fortunate to be able to take a month off to reset to my life it makes me so sad that there are so many people in the world in similar situations who dont have access to the tools and resources they need

clean_text: i find that the exhaustion caused by the current state of the us laboring system is causing more burnout in the population however due to increasing acceptance of mental health conditions and the resulting spread of easily accessible mental health information to the public people who are simply experiencing exhaustion have been classifying themselves as burnt out as someone who experiences clinical burnout this has brought me to many personal experiences when in telling someone i am burnt out there is an expectation placed upon me to simply keep going the misidentification of burnout by those experiencing exhaustion leads to the belief that burnout is simply a period of low energy and not a potentially dangerous mental health condition this then leads to the mistreatment of those experiencing clinical burnout placing them in a position that may worsen their condition there is also a heavy expectation which this video promotes that burnout is a set of specific symptoms that occur in a neurotypical format in reality especially for those who are neurodivergent burnout is a collection of ranging symptoms that have the ability to fluctuate burnout for a neurodivergent brain is going to show a different collection of potential symptoms than those identified for neurotypical people a few of which are shared in this video this perpetuation that burnout only occurs in ways the neurotypical brain conceives makes it more difficult for neurodivergent people to identify when they are in a period of burnout especially for those who are alexithymic this also means that treatment for burnout as recommended for neurotypical burnout isnt always successful in treating burnout for neurodivergent people im glad that big think has made a video detailing burnout to help those experiencing it identify their condition but i am dissatisfied with the lack of explanation and acceptance of different types of burnout

clean_text: as someone born in the us but living the last years in the netherlands its very interesting to see how differently the subject of burnout is addressed in each country in the us the best burnout treatment most people can hope for is a compassionate boss that will help prioritize your mental health by making small temporary adjustments to your workload in the netherlands youre able to take up to two years off with a government mandated minimum of your pay to allow you to focus on your mental health and truly treat your symptoms and many companies will even add additional pay up to of your salary and yes we do pay high taxes for the privilege of prioritizing mental health other healthcare transportation education etc but in my mind its absolutely worth every penny to know that if and when i need help im able to seek it regardless of preexisting conditions or financial pressures not trying to push this structure on anyone else just some food for thought for those that might share a similar vision for a balanced and secure human existence
translated: as someone born in the us but living the last years in the netherlands its very interesting to see how differently the subject of burnout is addressed in each country Making small temporary adjustments to your workload in the netherlands Youure able to take up to two years off with a government mandated minimum of your pay to allow you to focus on your mental health and Truly Treat Your Symptoms and many compans will event Pay High Taxes for the Privilege of Prioritizing Mental Health Other Healthcare Transportation Education etc. but in my mind absolutely worth every penny to know that if and when I need help imle to seek it regardless of preexisting conditions Anyone else just some food for those

clean_text: i would have liked a last piece about recovering from established long term burnout this is the hardest because the preventative measures probably still apply but they take on the quality of more things you are supposed to be doing more demands my one criticism of the piece is that i think limiting burnout to work factors creates an incomplete picture personal demands can definitely play a role single moms is probably the most often cited though in my case an elderly parent was the biggest factor the reason i got served this clip is that long term burnout is a big topic at the moment on the neurodivergent channels adhd and autism neurodivergence adds some tricky variables it certainly can make you more vulnerable to burnout and certain neurodivergent traits strongly resemble the symptoms of burnout which makes untangling what is a result of what that much harder not least because some of the traits that resemble burnout may in fact come from experiencing the causes of burnout throughout all areas of a neurodivergent persons life these days this type of ongoing stress is often misattributed as trauma and i appreciate that this piece talks about stress as a root i do feel a need to clarify one last thing about that however burnout as an outcome is distinguishable from stress but it flows from persistent stress if you are trying to preempt burnout its very important not to fall into looking at your situation and going its just stress theres nothing just about stress no one can live a stress free life just as no one can avoid being exposed to any carcinogens but too much of either too constantly is likely to lead to health problems and in the case of stress those problems are often mental health related alas the concerns often get applied only to whether you have a heart attack or a stroke but many of us can tell you that breakdowns can be debilitating too persistent stress does damage to all systems especially the prefrontal cortex it is long past time for business and society to stop pretending that what does not kill us makes us stronger
